_exec_summary.SummaryText:
2.1 Corporate Statement

Clean Harbors La Porte (Facility) operates a hazardous waste treatment and storage facility (TSDF) in accordance with a Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) hazardous waste license issued by the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ).  The Facility strives to conduct its business and operations in strict conformity with all applicable laws, and in a safe and responsible manner.  The Facility has always placed the highest priority on the health and safety of its employees and members of the community in which it operates.

The Facility is subject to the provisions of the Accidental Release Prevention requirements because regulated toxic and flammable liquids are present in quantities which, on occasion, exceed the regulatory thresholds for these substances. Accordingly, the Facility has prepared a Risk Management Plan.

The Facility 's accidental release prevention program involves a unified approach that integrates technologies, procedures and management practices.  The Facility is designed, constructed, inspected, maintained and operated in a manner so as to minimize the risk of exposure to employees and the public to hazardous materials managed at the site, and in conformity with all governmental regulations.

The Facility has a comprehensive Inspection Plan, which requires daily, weekly, monthly, and annual inspections of its processes, equipment and management practices.

The Facility maintains a Contingency Plan, which prescribes procedures to be followed in the event of a fire or release at the facility.  The Contingency Plan includes procedures for notifying local, state and federal emergency response officials of incidents, and specifies arrangements made with emergency responders to ensure an effective response in the event of an emergency.

The Facility has a training program which ensures that each employee receives the training necessary to enable him/her to safely and effectively carry out his/her job responsi

bilities.  Included in the facility training plan are training modules which instruct employees on the hazards of the regulated substances stored at the site, the procedures for evacuation from the facility, procedures for responding to releases, and procedures for notification of incidents to both facility personnel and offsite emergency responders.  In addition to the initial training that all employees receive, each employee receives refresher training on an annual basis.

2.2 Accident Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The FacilityA?s release prevention program and emergency response procedures have been developed in accordance with the EPA requirements for hazardous waste facilities described in the federal regulations 40 CFR 264 Subpart C and Subpart D. In addition, these requirements have been adopted by the State of Texas and incorporated by the TCEQ in a facility IHW permit #50225.

Release prevention policies include: design and operation of the facility; communication equipment; testing and maintenance of equipment; access to communication and alarm systems; aisle space requirements and arrangements with local authorities. 

Emergency response policies include: designation of emergency coordinators; detailed emergency action procedures including notification of local authorities; lists of emergency response equipment; emergency phone numbers; evacuation procedures and reporting requirements.

2.3 Description of the Facility and Regulated Substances 

The Facility is a commercial hazardous waste management facility engaged in the storing and bulking of hazardous waste regulated under RCRA.  Hazardous waste is stored in containers in enclosed warehouses. The facility has the potential to store propane (100%) and butane (100%), which are regulated RMP chemicals, in quantities greater than the threshold planning quantity of 10,000 pounds. Off-specification or out dated propane and butane are received from customers in compressed gas cylinders

The specific elements of The Facility's Contingency Plan are discussed in Section 6.0 of this RMP.

2.7 Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The facility has organized its management system to effectively address all hazards and potential risks. Thorough accident investigation and personnel training are necessary to support continual improvement in the facility safety program.  The Facility's accident investigation procedure and training plan are designed to incorporate new technology improvement in safety as well as lessons learned from accidents. This information is shared on a national level between Environmental Health and Safety (EH&S) professionals and company management to increase awareness and improve safety procedures.  

Current information about the safe handling of all chemicals present at the facility is available to employees, and can be readily interpreted by emergency response team staff and the Facility Emergency Coordinators when questions arise from public safety officials regarding potential risks to the community.  All of these features of the RMP and the integrated risk management program at this site lead to operations that meet or exceed the state and federal regulatory requirements applicable to the facility's operations.
